awd_titl_txt: Characterizing Star Formation in the Tidal Debris of Minor Galaxy Mergers
awd_abstract_narration:
Karen Knierman is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at Arizona State University. Mergers between galaxies of different mass are very common in the universe and may affect the majority of galaxies including our own Milky Way galaxy. The debris produced in these minor mergers is a unique place to study the factors that influence star formation since it is away from the dense centers of the mergers. Due to the lower pressures and densities in the tidal debris, this study probes the lower bounds of where star formation is possible. To attract a diverse workforce in science and engineering, a new astronomy outreach initiative, Multicultural Milky Way, will engage under-served populations in Arizona in learning about our Milky Way and other galaxies. Arizona is home to many diverse populations with rich cultural histories such as Mayan, Navajo, and Apache. Linking astronomy practiced by one's indigenous culture to that of Western astronomy may increase the interest in science. Through multicultural planetarium shows and associated hands-on activities, under-served families will learn how the Milky Way is represented in different cultures and about the science of galaxies. 

This project will characterize how star formation occurs in tidal debris and the origin of the debris. Narrowband infrared images of molecular hydrogen will provide a picture of the hot molecular gas component and how the interstellar medium of the tail has been molded by in-situ star formation. This project will provide the first survey of molecular hydrogen in minor mergers. With optical, H-alpha, and submillimeter observations, these data will give a more complete picture of star formation in tidal debris of minor mergers. Using the metallicity calculated from spectra of tidal clumps in minor mergers compared to regions in the parent spiral and dwarf galaxy, the origin of the tidal debris of minor mergers can be determined: the cannibalized dwarf, the outer regions of the spiral, or the center. In addition, a new astronomy outreach initiative, Multicultural Milky Way, will engage under-served populations in Arizona in learning about stars and galaxies. New shows featuring how different cultures view the Milky Way will be created for the Digistar static and STARLAB portable planetariums. STARLAB shows and associated new hands-on activities will feature at Community Astronomy Nights around Arizona. For authentic assessment, evaluation techniques and procedures will be developed with education mentors.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied star formation and its influences in the tidal debris of minor galaxy mergers and performed related public outreach with under-served Arizona families. The scientific results of this project help characterize how star formation occurs in tidal debris. Prior optical and H-alpha imaging were combined with new H-alpha imaging to measure recent star formation rates in these tidal debris areas.  New submillimeter and radio observations measure the amount of molecular and neutral gas in these tidal debris regions.  Comparing the measured star formation rate to the molecular gas mass estimates the star formation efficiency. Together, these data give a more complete picture of star formation in the tidal debris of minor mergers.

Observations of the TALES sample of 15 minor mergers were taken in optical, near infrared, submillimeter, and radio wavelengths.  As part of this project, 13 minor mergers (2 previously observed) were observed in CO (1-0) with the ARO 12 meter.  Locations within the tidal tails were chosen to correspond with knots of recent star formation or more luminous regions of the tidal tails.  Results show significant detections of cold molecular gas in 12 tidal tail regions out of 22 regions observed in 13 mergers.  To determine the motion and amount of neutral gas, observations of 7 minor mergers using the 21 cm HI line with the EVLA complement the archival data for remainder of the sample.  To complete H-alpha observations, 1 merger was observed with the VATT.   Narrowband infrared images of molecular hydrogen provide a picture of the hot molecular gas component and how the interstellar medium (ISM) of the tail has been molded by in situ star formation. The first survey of warm molecular gas in minor mergers using the 2.12 micron line of molecular hydrogen was done through deep observations of the 7 closest minor mergers with UKIRT and the Bok 90-inch. The 2.12 micron line of molecular hydrogen was detected in the tidal bridge of minor merger Arp 269.  Star formation rates of tidal debris from narrowband H-alpha images are compared to the molecular gas surface density of those regions using CO (1-0) observations.  Using the gas depletion time, the ratio of the molecular gas mass to the star formation rate from H-alpha imaging, we estimate the star formation efficiency of these regions and compare them to normal spiral galaxies.  Of the 14 tidal debris areas in minor mergers studied, 4 have highly efficient star formation, 4 have star formation consistent with normal galaxies, and 6 have very low star formation efficiency.  These results show that tidal debris regions have star formation efficiencies that can vary widely, possibly indicating that the formation mechanism of the tidal debris plays a role. 

The new outreach initiative, Multicultural Milky Way, partnered the School of Earth and Space Exploration (SESE) at Arizona State University (ASU) with local families, particularly in under-served areas. Because learning about science as practiced by one’s indigenous culture can increase interest in science, planetarium resources were gathered to link Arizona students with their culture(s).  The ASU STARLAB portable planetarium has cylinders that include Navajo, Chinese, Hindu, and African sky cultures, as well as Greek mythological stories.  The Maya Skies cylinder was purchased with funds from this project.  Planetarium shows that included information about the Milky Way in different cultures, were given to over 2200 people.  This included 650 Native American K-5 students at Salt River Elementary, about 200 at-risk and minority high school students at Mesa Community College, and over 130 college students. At Biltmore Preparatory Academy in Phoenix, about 600 students participated in combined Spanish and English STARLAB presentations. In total, about 1900 K-12 students were directly reached by STARLAB shows during this project. 

Six teacher workshop events trained 75 teachers and 21 ASU students.  These 75 teachers can then use STARLAB with their classes (about 150 students) meaning this training could impact 11,250 students this year and in future years.  Also, Navajo County schools have organized to borrow STARLAB for three weeks at a time to use in multiple schools since they are located over 2 hours from ASU. Attendance at school and community events netted about 2000 students and community members participating with STARLAB. At the Community Astronomy Event in rural Heber, Arizona over 300 people experienced STARLAB. My hands-on activities relating to galaxies have impacted about 3000 people per year (about 9000 total), over several events open to families and the general public such as Pascua Yaqui STEAM Night, ASU events, Girl Scout, and rural Arizona community events.  Supplemental materials for Starlab shows, including Milky Way info for different cultures in Starlab, and the instructions and printables for galaxy related hands-on activities have been posted on the Exploring Galaxies website.
